title: Understanding the Equilibrium Constant
text: The equilibrium constant, K, is a ratio of the concentrations of products to reactants, each raised to the power of their coefficients in the balanced equation.

title: Identifying the Products and Reactants
text: In the given reaction, identify which compounds are the products and which are the reactants. Remember, products are on the right side of the equation, and reactants are on the left.

title: Using Square Brackets for Concentrations
text: When writing the expression for K, use square brackets to denote the concentration of each species. For example, the concentration of NH3 is written as [NH3].

title: Applying the Coefficients as Exponents
text: In the expression for K, raise the concentration of each species to the power of its coefficient in the balanced equation. For example, if NH3 has a coefficient of $$2$$, write it as $${[NH3]}^2$$.

title: Constructing the Expression for K
text: Combine the concentrations of the products and reactants into a single expression for K. Place the product concentrations in the numerator and the reactant concentrations in the denominator.
